The food is amazing! The uni pasta is #1 most popular and that for a good reason. Don't really care for the bruschetta but that's just my opinion. It's still good.  Service could be better but hey it wasn't bad. Everyone worked together to try and provide great service and that's all that matters.

This was easily one of the best meals I've ever had. Everything was delicious, the service was exceptional, and the restaurant was empty. :) My bf and I were originally going to do to Lee's BBQ, but after reading Yelp reviews we changed our minds and I had been wanting to go to Trattoria Nakamura-Ya for a couple months after I found it when picking up food from Big Wong's next door. Italian-Asian Fusion...YES PLEASE!!

Turns out they have happy hour from 2 to 5, we got there with 8 minutes to spare and the waitress totally hooked us up and placed all our HH orders first while we perused the full menu. Off HH we got the Fried "Jidori" Chicken, Italian Spring Roll, Grilled "Kurobuta" Sausage Ratatouille, Green Tea Gelato, and Soy Milk Panna Cotta. From the Main dishes, we shared the "Waygu" Beef & "Kurobuta" Pork Hamburg Steak. 

EVERYTHING was delicious, I would add a touch of something sweeter to the Green Tea gelato, like a condensed milk drizzle or something to take the slight bitter/earthiness of the green tea but other than that... I really enjoyed everything I ate. The hamburg steak was the best I've ever had in my life, from anywhere. The service was impeccable and I super enjoyed that we were there while it was empty. We will be going back over and over. 

My bf and I usually have the best restaurant luck, but we were hit or miss for a second however after going here, we know we are back on track.

So we are riding around the strip in the limo... Hunger started to strike.... We were thinking hey let's eat something nice... But not break the bank. 
As usual we Yelped it hard... Saw this place, and Sakino had it book marked. Let's go. 
Pulled up tough in the parking lot. Se parking lot as Monta and Zen. Zen is good.. So we're like ehhh, fail safe. 
From the outside, lookin grim. Get inside, THIS place looks Great! Lovely decor, good mood lighting, very clean. Also, everyone inside is for real Japanese, which being from Japan, my wife feels more comfortable with. She's not racists, but she also ain't a fan of mobbin into a Japanese joint with all the servers being from Texas hehee... Anyways. 
This place looked good. The food presentation was excellent. The taste was amazing! I had tonkatsu and it was to die for. Sakino had the highly recommended uni pasta! The recommendations weren't false. It was delicious. They served us warm rolls with our Mozzarella Caprese... Mmmm! We finished it off with a Okinawa sugar desert! Which jumped off the menu, since my wife is FROM Okinawa so we were like hell yea! Great job Nakamura! It almost got 5 stars as we know Nakamuras in Okinawa too, but the kanji indicated its the mainland (Japan) Nakamura... Still good though. Very very friendly and typical very polite servers! We even over heard the waitress talking to her waitress friend about Shingeki no kyojin hehehe, score. A strategically placed big screen vizio had Monday Night Football on at low volume so I could "not watch" (but really watch) the game without offending my dinner mates, in this case, my wife lol. 
Uni Pasta
Tonkatsu
Rolls
Rice
Caprese
Desert
Pepsi
15% tip
$70 TOTAL... I'm down with that. For sure with going back. For sure a recommendation to anyone looking for a truly unique and very well done fusion between traditional Japanese and Italian foods. NEVER would've guessed you could marry these too cuisines... But Nakamura did it, and sis it well! ?????????????tre bein!

Saw this next door to Kabuto when we went for dinner and wanted to try it out! We came the next day for an early dinner before going to the airport. Neither of us were too hungry so we got the #1 most popular dish - uni tomato cream linguini ($26) - to share. 

Service was impeccable and the ambiance of the small restaurant was cozy and homey. Really lovely.

Freshly baked butter rolls will be served after you order. They're quite delicious with some really good butter.

The pasta came relatively quickly as the restaurant was pretty empty. Portion size was pretty good considering it's uni. I really liked it. The uni was rich and creamy, more sweet than briny. There weren't too many chunks of uni, as to be expected, but if you do get one with a bite of pasta, it's heavenly.

The cream sauce is on the heavier side, so if you're eating it on your own, get a starter salad or come hungry.

Japanese-style Italian is pretty new in the States so it might take some getting used to. But Nakamura-ya is a great place to go to try it out!

This random Japanese place serves some excellent pastas.  It's quite unexpected for a place like this. We ordered bruschetta for appetizer, squid ink pasta and linguine with scallop, shrimp, and salted roe in a white creamy sauce.  All dishes were delicious.  The server was also very nice, will go back to try other dishes.

Tried his top dish today, the uni. Creamiest thing I've ever tasted without the heavy "cream" feeling. I sat at the bar and watched Chef Nakamura work his magic. As he was frying up some clams for me, some grease splattered up and hit his face. Ouch! 

He was delightful to talk with though. A very charming and humble man.

The clams and bruschetta were special. Top notch dining.

I'm a big fan of Kaiseki Ryori because of it's delicacy, simplicity, and elegance.  Now days, I noticed that quiet a few Japanese restaurants are specialized in a foreign cuisine in Vegas and I am very happy to try them out :) 

We stumbled upon this restaurant on Saturday evening around 5:30pm.  With my small knowledge on Japanese/Italian fusion cooking techniques, I was just assuming that there aren't many dishes can be created into Japanese flavored pasta dishes on the menu besides conventional dishes.  All I could imagine and think of ingredients were some sort of flying fish roe on angel hair pasta, sesame oil flavored dish, yuzu citron sauce, or the dish with ginger garnish.  Well, I was wrong.  There were so many items to choose from.  And also, they had 7 to 8 different style of dishes for Special of the Day. 
Finally, we decided to share two dishes from the Special Menu:
1. "Casago Black Mussel ($25.95)"
     -Very tender & sweet fish
     -Small size of winter black mussels w/ tangy tomato sauce(it was sure to  impress!!)
2. "Scallop & Shrimp Pasta (under $20)"
     -The texture of pasta was just right
     -Good portion for two people
     -Scallops & Shrimps were well cooked( not tough or rubbery tasty at all)
*I was thinking that the chef was making sure these two ingredients were comparable in size so they had similar cooking time for the best taste :) 

Overall, I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of food and very charming ambiance.  It was definitely a cozy dining experience for me.  Maybe, they could accommodate no more than 30 customers at one time.  There are still many dishes I'd love to try out from the menu, like Black Squid Ink Pasta and some other creative desserts.  The servings are on the medium to large sizes which encourage sharing with companions.  After experiencing Japanese Italian dishes, I want to say that they are a perfect culinary marriage!
Very interesting concept and everything was delicious. Only lost a star because of the portions.

A Treasure to behold and Enjoy .
This charming cozy restaurant is a gem of a find   A surprise Birthday present to this restaurant , I immensely liked. The Manila clam with Tarako spaghetti .  The fusion of the Japanese - Italian dish was sublime !
The fresh Seabass appetizer rivaled any world class restaurant in both freshness , creativity and taste .
I will be a repeat customer .

Trattoria Nakamura-Ya has been on my Yelp radar for a while now, but it didn't top my list of must-eat places mostly because I've never had uni much less squid ink.  When the bestie invited me to dine there during their 3rd anniversary, the two most popular dishes of Linguini Uni Tomato Cream and the Spaghetti "Ikasumi" Squid Ink were half-off the normal price ($26.95 and $19.95, respectively).  Trusting that girlfriend wouldn't steer me wrong, I figured this would be an excellent time to finally try these exotic (to me) dishes.  Arriving around 6:00pm on a Wednesday, there was a line at the door as expected.  Checking in with the hostess, you can leave your phone number and get a call when your table is ready.  We waited 45 minutes for a table to open up.  Once seated, we were waited on quickly.  We ordered both the uni and squid ink pastas, more than enough for the two of us to share.  The Linguini Uni arrived at the table first and it was definitely delicious; I really loved the tomato cream sauce.  I couldn't really distinguish the taste of the uni, however, so I will have to try uni in another dish some other time.  The squid ink spaghetti came next and I was already getting full from the uni dish.  Other than its black color, this pasta is not as scary as it looked (to me).  If you tasted it blindfolded, you would not expect it to be squid ink or black; it tasted a bit garlicky and was very flavorful.  But, the uni was my favorite of the two and I would have it again.  Japanese and Italian fusion is an interesting concept and I look forward to another visit to try the Miso Carbonara and to have more of the uni.

Hubby and I rarely indulge in pasta so we decided to treat ourselves on our weekend in Vegas (which are getting fewer and farther between nowadays).  

We'd been to Nakamura once before with a bigger group of friends we met here.  I don't recall being blown away though hubby really enjoyed his gorgonzola and natto pasta.  So here we came for a late dinner, after watching a show.

We started with their beef carpaccio (possibly the star of the evening though a third of it was inexplicably cooked).  We also ordered their home-made garlic bread which came with some prosciutto on top.  Also very good.

Hubby went with the Manila Clams and Tarako while I decided to splurge and get the Uni Tomato Cream with Scallops.  

When our dishes came, I immediately recognized the kind of pasta hubby got...brothy and sort of on the bland side.  The saving grace was the shiso which gave it a flavor boost but otherwise, neither of us really preferred this style of pasta.

My Uni Tomato Cream with Scallops was better than hubby's but still not mind-blowing.  I wish there would have been 25% more uni flavor, that the pasta was more al dente and the scallops were not so well done.

At this point, we definitely felt the appetizers outshined the pasta.  
Service was friendly though it did take a while for us to get out of there. 

So I guess we weren't super disappointed in our meal but, as we do, we ended up going somewhere else for dinner #2 shortly after.
Uni pasta with tomato cream. It's #1 for a reason. Great to escape the strip. Only a dozen tables so the ambiance is great. Not overwhelming.

I have waited literal YEARS to try Trattoria Nakamura-Ya and finally took the leap during their 4th anniversary! The deal included half off (or close to) their two most popular dishes - the uni cream pasta and squid ink pasta.

SERVICE

As with pretty much almost any Japanese restaurant, service is ON POINT. Waitresses knew their stuff, were quick, friendly, polite, and just all around lovely. The only drawback was that I ordered a daikon salad appetizer and it did not come until the end of the meal...Free refills on bread totally made me forget about that.

There is gratuity for parties of 6+

ATMOSPHERE

Cozy and warm and oh-so-classy. My friend got ginger ale and it came in a nice glass bottle with a serving glass! Yes, I get amused by simple things. Appropriate choice of music as well.

Warning: space is limited, so there is a wait during peak hours.

FOOD

Bread rolls - they were so magically warm and soft on the inside but crisp on the outside. Such a good starter!
Uni cream pasta - perfectly balanced, not too heavy, generous amount of actual uni, well-portioned
Squid ink pasta - stains!, taste was pretty good, not my favorite
My friend's pasta with kurobuta sausage - decent
----came with calamari - wonderfully crisp and not overcooked!
----salad - standard
Daikon salad - refreshing and tart from the plum and sundried tomatoes, wish this came before I finished my uni cream pasta

I will definitely go back for their prix fix meals.

Nakamura-Ya is pretty impressive. 

The prices are reasonable and portions are plenty. 

All of the pastas I've tried are amazing. They bring fresh bread when you first sit down. 
Salads were good too. Where else do you find Italian and Japanese food combined? GO!

It was my first time here and realized it would be almost impossible not to order the pasta with uni and tomato cream sauce every time I visit. Trattoria Nakamura-Ya is conveniently located in a strip mall in Chinatown, so you can stain your shirt with squid ink pasta and get it cleaned on the same day. It is also easy to find because there is a bright shining light on the restaurant that has the restaurant's name in all capitals. The meal started off with the bruschetta, which were actually kind of good. The octopus with wasabi cream was too good to explain in words and the other two were just great. We also ordered the beef carpaccio and cheese platter as appetizers. The beef carpaccio was very good but it could have used some more arugula for more of a textural contrast. Cheese platters usually don't excite me but this one was amazing. However, the mini caprese salad that came with the cheeses was overdressed. It was more like balsamic soup with ovalini mozzarella, basil, and cherry tomatoes. For the entr√©e course, everyone ordered the uni pasta which was super great. Most Americans do not like uni, or sea urchin, because of it's booger-like texture. This uni was very smooth after being blended with cream and tomatoes. The pasta also came with scallops, which tasted amazing but lacked the hard sear it needed. Trattoria Nakamura-Ya is a great restaurant to visit when you are in the Las Vegas area.
Been here a few times for lunch but now the hours have changed to dinner only.  Food is great and so it atmosphere.  Bummed they don't have the hirame salad anymore!

I lived in Japan for almost two years, so I was very excited to find an authentic Japanese Italian Trattoria.

The Uni Tomato Cream was nice but I disagree with the most posts that this was the best on the menu.  It was not as good as Capriciossa spaghetti or others from Japan.

The best dish that we tried was the shrimp and scallop pasta with creme sauce.  That was a  very worthy dish.  Enjoy

I liked the idea of the prix fixe menu, yet was a chepo and went with 17.99. I would have liked to try the tomato uni sauce for 2$ more. Service was great, but it was really hot in there when we sat down, it chilled off a little after a while. My pasta was just a little too tough, and I'm familiar with the sausage they use hoping they did in house, but didn't taste any different. Ravioli with spinach and ricotta cooked perfect al dente with tomato cream and shrimp was awesome. I asked if the fresh bread was shokupan and it wasn't but still very good (Pillsbury style) . Still with all my     discrepancies it's worth the trip to try it out fall in love with a dish and go back.

Everyone is raving about Uni Tomato CreamSpaghetti but it is just an okay to me, too much spaghetti, little uni and the tomato sauce overpowers the uni taste. i was pretty disappointed since its their signature dish. Oshima uni spaghetti is much better.

Excellent
Fried Octopus
Salmon Capaccio:
Mussels Three Way

Good
Green Tea Panna Cotta

So-so
Uni Spaghetti
Squid Ink Spaghetti

Bit of twist in Italian dish, I had great time and great food. hamburg steak was just like I imaginedto be with nice mushroom gravy. Desserts plates are awesome. Willing to go back to try other items in menu

Ok, I'll admit it, I only tried this place because I saw it in the Desert magazine. 
Right next door to my favorite sushi place, Trattoria faced an uphill battle to win over a skeptical diner who longed for fatty tuna located on the other side of the wall.
Like the article in the magazine, I ordered the uni spaghetti. I'm a sell out, I know.
Now here's where Trattoria not only won the uphill battle, they took the whole mountain range. Uni, one of the most vile foods I've ever eaten, mixed with noodles, one of my all time favorite foods, caught me by surprise. I didn't savor the dish, I destroyed it! 
Apparently, licking your plate clean is frowned upon in public, but I wasn't going to let one morsel of food escape. I'm sure they have other outstanding entrees here, but uni spaghetti is my go to dish.

Great Tokyo Italian Fusion.    Wonderful selection will keep you coming back for more.   The uni linguine was really good but I would not have known it was uni for the taste.  Nevertheless my wife and I tried each other's orders and we were very happy with all the food we ordered and would like to return to try more from their exotic selections on their menu.

Honestly, the Uni pasta is too hyped up. It was really thick and nothing else to it besides the Uni so for $26 it isn't worth it. It was overpowered by the tomato cream sauce so the Uni flavor was barely there. 

We also got the kobe outskirt steak and I would give that a 2 star. The dish came with a few slices of steak and garnishment. For $20 I think the restaurant can add a side salad to it. The steak itself didn't have a great taste to it. Tasted like reheated microwaved steak...yeah kinda gross.

The BEST main course  dish we had was the SPICY CHICKEN JIDORI pasta. That was the saving grace of me returning to this place ever again. the sauce had a great flavor and a good kick to it. It wasn't heavy and you get some protein with the chicken. 

For appetizers we got the mussels escargot. It came with 6 pieces and 3 different flavors. I only liked the cheese flavored one, but my sister liked the miso flavor...so it might be something you'd like to try on your own and find out for yourself. 

The soft shell crab was great. The sauce was really good. It was my favorite appetizer that we ordered and we ordered a lot. Everything else was just mediocre.

Dessert, definitely go for the Panna Cotta. I'm not a dessert person because I'm not a big fan of sweets, but even the Panna Cotta got me eating it.

Five stars for vision, but currently, I'd say moreso around three for execution. I had the mid-level fixed price menu, which came with an appetizer (bruschetta), pasta (salmon), and drink (iced oolong tea). The drink was a soft drink, while I am used to fresh tea so I didn't enjoy it as much. The bruschetta was good, not quite great but good, with three different kinds of toppings on bread. The salmon entree was solid, but I'd say unspectacular--the flavor wasn't quite as pronounced or sophisticated as I would've liked. The pasts was more toward al dente,  though this is more a preference than a critique--I am not a fan of al dente. The dessert, a tiramisu, was solid, not the most memorable but definitely solid. The service was professional but not quite as observant as I would've preferred.

It's three stars but if I am dichotomizing it, it'd be a recommendation because the vision is clear and distinct.

My friends had hyped this place up as the best pasta they've ever had, so naturally I had to go. Was it the best? No. Was it still really good? Yes! 
We tried four different dishes and each of them tasted so good I could have easily eaten everything on the table myself. Trattoria was very successful in blending two different cuisines to make one sound dish. 
The down side though was in the details. We ordered two uni tomato cream with scallops. I wish there was more of an uni taste, but what was really disappointing was one plate had a satisfying number of scallops and the other literally had one piece. For $6 more to get one scallop felt like a rip off. 
I was tempted to give this place a 3 star, but at the end of the day, all the dishes tasted great and I would go back in a heart beat, although maybe not upgrade to the scallop dish.

Wow. I loved this. The food was great and the service was friendly. 
We ordered off their lunch menu and the good was reasonable and delicious. Not much of the fusions foods are found on that menu but the pasta was perfectly cooked and tasted great. 
I would recommend this place to anyone and I know I'll be coming back more and more!

I love the idea of this restaurant.   I'm all about Asian fusion and I had never thought to mix Italian and Japanese.   

Overall, it was a pleasant experience.   The service was good.   Our server gave us the specials, asked us if we had questions and made sure we got everything we needed. 

I appreciate that they have specialty menus for vegetarians, vegans, gluten free, etc.  I just wish I had looked at one.  Lol.   

The food was good.   It wasn't spectacular but it wasn't bad either.  The portions are pretty small for the pricing.  I also found a hair in my meal but I didn't say anything to my server as it was in a part I wasn't going to eat anyway. 

 With the competition next door (Kubota and Raku) I can see why they do what they do.   We decided we'd come again to try different items and see if we're blown away next time.

Really enjoyed eat here. Coming from LA for a quick getaway and i stumbled upon this place when i was driving around during lunch time. 

I tried their fricked chicken appetizer, their bruschetta 3 ways and the squid ink pasta. They were all outstanding! My favor was the bruschetta , superb flavors. Coming back tomorrow to try other items on their menu!

I have been wanting to try uni pasta FOREVER but couldn't find anything in my area. On a last minute trip to vegas, I was told about this place from a local. I made a late (11:15pm) reservation and the hostess was so sweet. We had to go there straight from the airport because our flight was delayed, but the hostess did a great job of keeping us updated and even offered to put in our order before we got there. When we finally arrived our little table was all set up and we were the only ones in the restaurant. My husband got the uni pasta special with scallops and I got the regular uni pasta. Both were amazing. So creamy and rich. Every bite had a piece of buttery uni on it. It was heaven!! Thank you so much to our hostess/waitress and all the chefs for letting us stay late to enjoy that delicious food. We loved it!!

I've always struggled with Japanese-Italian infusion and even after dining here at Nakamura-Ya, I still continue to struggle to enjoy it. 

This place is small and the parking lot situation is not so great. It's in the same plaza as Raku and Monta, which are popular dining spots on Spring Mountain Road.

Tried a few dishes, but I'll highlight some notables.

Uni Pasta - you usually can't go wrong with uni with anything, right? If you like uni, you'll like this dish. Apparently, this is their number one seller. I would say the dish could use some more uni, but overall it's a well-balanced dish. Savory sea flavor from the uni and creaminess from the tomato cream sauce enables this dish to warrant the #1 position. Must try if you dine here.

Squid Ink Pasta - with every bite the sea essence flavor comes through. Yes, the pasta is inked black, but overlook it and you'll enjoy every bite. This dish is served with sauteed calamari, which tasted fresh and with just enough chewy texture.

Wagyu Meat Sauce Kinoko Spaghetti - flavorful, but a bit too creamy. I could barely taste the meat sauce and the amount of cream overpowered any other flavors. The spaghetti was cooked properly, but probably a bit softer than al dente. The kinoko mushrooms tasted acceptable, but then again, that cream sauce overpowered all other potential flavors.

Pan Fried Calamari - too chewy and I had to chew each piece for quite a while. The lemon butter sauce was pretty good and the toasted almonds helped add some texture to this appetizer. Lots of potential, but the star of the dish, the calamari, failed to meet expectations.

Service was friendly and prompt. The combo packages can save you a few bucks - especially if you get some red or white wine. More like 3.5 stars and potential 4 or 5 for me once I have the opportunity to try some of their other top 10 dishes.

The caring that goes into the food and to us as their customers- we will definitely be back!

We had the fried oysters and soft shell crab for appetizers.  

For entrees, pasta with shrimp and mushroom and the linguini with clams.  Both hit the spot! 

The linguini with clams had just the right amount of garlic flavor, and the broth (yes broth) was set somewhere in the delicious and comfort realm.

I was only afforded one bite of the pasta with shrimp and mushroom- and from there- the bowl was almost back to clean when the servers cleared our dishes. 

We'll be back-probably again and again!
It was a hit or miss for me. Appetizer was good but 2 pasta dishes were average salmon fettuccine being better of the two

I ordered the kinoko pasta and it was amazing. The wagyu beef based sauce is so flavorful, it addicting. We also had the salmon, which was cooked perfectly and tasty. The karage octopus was a great start to the meal as well. I am so happy to have found this spot and add it to my list of great places to eat in Las Vegas.

I've tried very few Japanese Italian fusion restaurants, but the result seems to be always good.  Never is the pasta cooked past al dente and that is really important to me.  Also, I really wanted to try the uni tomato cream pasta.  Wow, the yelp pics had me salivating!

Uni tomato cream pasta- Delicious and def had the uni taste.  Almost too rich though.  The sauce was so thick, it was almost like melted velveeta.  7.75/10

Squid Ink pasta- Very garlicky and oniony.  I thought it was cute how it left the black ring around everyone's mouth.  I actually liked this better than the uni!  8/10

Mushroom Meat Pasta- Sorry, I forget the name right now.  Kinoko?  It was on the happy hour menu for well under half the price of the other pastas that we ordered.  This was really good, too.  Very, very flavorful.  I want some of this now!  8/10

Mentaiko Carbonara- Light in flavor and in taste esp when paired with the any of the other pastas.  Not much mentaiko.  6.5/10

Eggrolls- I want to say there was cheese and some meat in there.  Thought it was fine.  5/10

Bruschetta- There were three different flavors:  tuna, mozzarella, and I forget the third one now...haha, sorry.  I think it had wasabi, and it was actually my favorite of the three.  They were all very good, though.  7.5/10

Dark Chocolate gelato- Rich and you get two small scoops along with a vanilla wafer.  It was fine.  5/10.  

I would give this 4.5 stars, and would definitely return to try more of their pastas.  We came particularly for happy hour, but didn't end up ordering but one entree from the happy hour menu (and the appetizers were all from the HH menu).  It's good quality food for a fair price.  I can't wait to come back!

This place is so good. Service is great as the staff is very attentive. The linguine uni tomato cream pasta and halibut sashimi Japanese watercress salad were both delicious. I definitely want to come back and try their other dishes.

My boyfriend and I came here for their 5 year anniversary and their popular dishes were half-off. We were really intrigued by their uni pasta. I love uni, and my boyfriend hates it, but we both ordered it. We were too scared of the black squid ink pasta, and when I asked my boyfriend, "why on earth did you order an uni dish when you don't even like uni??"

"It's the most popular thing on the menu." Uh okay.
 
FOOD:

Bruschetta "Nakamura-ya" style: 3.5/5
It was good, but I felt like I could've gotten something better for my money like the calamari. But hey, I was feeling adventurous. The octopus, wasabi bite was interesting. The mozzarella, anchovy bite was creamy and very fishy, similar to salmon roe. The tuna bite was kind of just baked tuna on a cracker.

Uni Creamy Tomato Pasta: 4.5/5
(FOR UNI LOVERS) The pasta was good and the sauce was creamy and delicious. I couldn't really taste any uni though, which was a little disappointing because I love uni. I kind of expected the sauce to be blended with it, and the flavor to be a little more pronounced or even present. Or I would've even liked to see my pasta dish topped with a piece or two. Instead it kind of felt like a small, single piece was chopped and mixed in, and then half of it melted. 

Uni Creamy Tomato Pasta with Scallop: 4.5/5
(FOR UNI HATERS) My boyfriend and I reached the same consensus. The pasta was good, the sauce delicious, but no uni flavor in sight. His dish even lacked as many uni pieces as mine. Overall, he enjoyed his food, and the scallops were cooked perfectly. 

SERVICE: 5/5
The service was amazing here. Water cups never reached half empty, or even a quarter empty, before someone quickly refilled it. After we had eaten the last bite off of a dish, it was always promptly whisked away. The food came out quickly and they checked on us enough to make sure we were enjoying our meal. We felt really taken care of here.

PRICING: 3/5
I saw the lunch price specials, and they seem totally reasonable for the food quality and service. For their 5 year anniversary prices at dinner, it was also pretty fair. But for their normal dinner prices, I think it's a bit pricey. If their uni pasta actually tasted like it had uni it in, it would've been reasonable. But it didn't, and it felt like they were charging a premium price for a regular pasta dish.

OVERALL: 4/5
The staff is amazing. The food is great. The prices? A little too steep. Come during lunch or on an Anniversary night. Otherwise, you're definitely splurging on Japanese-Italian fusion that leans a little too close to Italian.

More than adequate staffing level at present, all chefs/cooks visible in the kitchen speak Japanese, the menu is possibly unique here in Las Vegas (aside from the sister restaurant Kabuki).  The minimalistic ambiance of this small restaurant just works for me. And if you want to photo-document your meal, sit at the "pasta bar" counter, the lighting there is adequate for simple food photography needs.

So Down to business.  A group of Yelpers were actually at the plaza where this new restaurant is located at last night (Monday), which is currently their only day off.  So I decided I was going to check them out the next evening after work.  As the chef, possibly the owner, handed us their business cards and a few menu (he was at the restaurant with a few others).

When I arrived at 7:30pm on Tuesday, the place had 4 tables occupied already, and I am pretty sure that everyone there, except yours truly, was a native Japanese.  I considered that a positive indicator for seeking authentic Japanese style rendition of Western cuisine.

The menu is pretty simple, pastas are on the specials board, while appetizers,salads, chef's special dishes are on a 2-sided menu. The dessert menu also offers some Western desserts with a Japanese twist. Menu prices are mostly in the $teens, but can quickly add up to a meal costing $30-40+ per person.

On my inaugural visit, I tried the Miso Carbonara for main course #1 and Kurobuta Tonkatsu "Nakamura-Ya" Style for main course #2.  

The  Miso Carbonara pasta dish was good, the flavor is obviously different from traditional Italian Carbonara pasta dishes, but the sauce was creamy with a mild flavor.  I personally would prefer the pieces of bacon to be cooked a bit more, but that is a personal preference of mine.  Check out the picture I posted if you are interested in trying out this item. Flavor: 3.5 stars. Presentation: 3.5 stars. Value: 3 stars.

Since I was still hungry, I went and ordered the Kurobuta Tonkatsu "Nakamura-Ya" Style from the Chef's Special Dishes portion of the menu.  It is a very delicious and juicy tonkatsu (fried pork cutlet) that is served with a tomato sauce, an asparagus and a button mushroom cut up as garnish.  The only thing I thought was missing was a starch component to the entree, like rice pilaf or something.  Then again, maybe the roll that is served with the meal is meant to serve that role.  Flavor: 5 stars. Presentation: 3 stars.  Value: 3 stars.

For dessert I had the Soy Milk Panna Cotta "Okinawa Black Sugar" Sauce for $5.95, but the Black Sesame Blanc Manger also looks very interesting on the menu.  The Panna Cotta was pretty good, I like the flavor, although the texture seems a bit firmed (like too much gelatin was used) to me. However, the Okinawa Black Sugar Sauce was the key component that makes this dessert.  The dessert is probably prepared by savory chefs, as some basic pastry chef attention to detail was amissed (utilized sprig of mint that had clear signs of pest feeding on the leaf as a very noticeable garnish just seems careless, and something that can easily be prevented). 

Anyway, I like this new addition to the Las Vegas restaurant scene, and can see myself paying the occasional visit when I am in the mood.

Location: In the same plaza as Raku, Monta Ramen, Big Won, Soul Oak Korean BBQ.  Very accessible if you are near the Chinatown area.

Parking:  3/5  Could easily gets crowded, but not filled to capacity where you have to look for nearby street parking.

Ambiance:  4.5/5  I like the execution of the interior decor and the lighting (dim in the main dining area, and well lite at the "pasta bar"counter.

Service:  4.5/5  Pleasant service by a small squad of friendly waitresses.

Value:  3.5/5  Not a cheap meal, but I do think you get what you pay for, plus there is not much competition for this kind of cuisine in Las Vegas at the moment.

Flavor:  4 stars overall, some dishes and items are executed better than others.  But the balance of flavor that is not too overpowering, and compliments the components of the dish is what will make you go back for more.

4 stars!  Bravo and welcome to Las Vegas Trattoria Nakamura-Ya!!!

Note:  They do accept AMEX.

Trattoria Nakamura-Ya is nestled in a tiny Chinatown strip mall among superstars such as Raku, Monta Ramen and Japanese Curry Zen.  We were waiting outside for the restaurant to open when the server saw us standing around and unlocked the door. She said we could sit anywhere we liked as she wasn't expecting a lot of business at that particular time of day. At first, we sat a small table for two, since it was just the two of us, but when she returned with our menus, she seemed appalled and had us move to a larger table. "No, no, no! You don't have to sit at such a small table!" After we were seated at the larger table, we received the regular menu and the special Happy Hour menu. The menus contained lots of food words we'd never heard of, as we'd pretty much only had sushi. Our server was so friendly and patient answering my many questions. I must have asked about half the menu! In the end, we decided to split an appetizer and entr√©e. 

After we ordered, she brought out dinner rolls and butter. Bread and butter at a Japanese restaurant??! Okay, I know. It's Tokyo-style Italian, but we really weren't expecting bread. Way cool! The bread and butter was actually pretty tasty! After we finished our bread, the Mushroom and Jidori Chicken Salad arrived at the table. It was fresh, crisp and a great combination of flavors. The vinaigrette was BOMB. It was complex, yet balanced. Deeeelicious. The Takana and Chicken Spaghetti arrived soon after and it was sitting in an inch of lemony, garlicky chicken broth. Very good and light. The pickled mustard greens were delicious and mild. Several of the jidori chicken pieces had chunks of blubbery fat attached, which was unappetizing, but overall a wonderful dish as the chicken was intensely flavorful. 

Perfectly matched prices and portions, as the happy hour prices were fair and the portions were not too large, roughly half the size of an American-style Italian restaurant entr√©e. Great spot in Chinatown for attentive service from the charming and smiley Tomoyo, well-paced dishes and delicious food.

Where to start where to start? this place is AMAZING! Walking in I felt extremely welcomed by our server Tomo! she sat us down and I just knew the food was going to be amazing!

we started off with the bread and HOLY CRAP! that bread was the best bread ive ever had for real! it was nonetheless uncomparable to any other bread! it was hot out of the oven, had butter on the side! aww man i can eat that all day. We also ordered the Uni Tomato Cream pasta, Fettuccine Salmon and Ikura and the Kobe Beef Carpaccio! Everything was sooo good! I will definitely come here again and again!

Tomo was our server and she was awesome!! Her hospitality was spot on and she was always helpful and there when we needed her! I wasnt able to get the other servers name who was helping us out as well! she was awesome herself :) Thank you nakamura! Ill be back soon!
Lunch menu is awesome. Today I had very testy tomato pasta with hint of Japanese flavor and fresh brewed coffee with soy panna cotta. Life makes sense again ;)
